text:
Hi! All

I am a new user of Portable Thunderbird and I would like to seek help from fellow users, who are more experienced, to solve a problem.

I think I should explain it first. I usually get my mails by POP using Thunderbird installed in my machine (Mine is a Gmail account). But I would like to use Portable Thunderbird at the Cybercafe where I usually surf the Web. According to the instructions given on the Portable Thunderbird website, I copy my profile from my machine into the profile folder of Thunderbird in my USB. At Cybercafe, I use the portable exe to download my mail by POP while surfing at the same time. When I get back to my place, I copy the profile in the USB into my machine again.

The problem is that the amount of my saved mails are daily growing larger. It is no problem in the machine but a real problem in the USB.

Is there anyway to remove mails saved in the profile of the Portable Thunderbird in my USB, and yet manage to use POP? I needn't keep them there.

cheers!

PDT

received: (qmail 88425 invoked from network); 31 Jan 2005 18:52:51 -0000
from rproxy.gmail.com (64.233.170.203) by mozdev.org with SMTP; 31 Jan 2005 18:52:51 -0000
by rproxy.gmail.com with SMTP id y7so190892rne for <portablethunderbird@mozdev.org>; Mon, 31 Jan 2005 10:49:13 -0800 (PST)
headers.subject: [Portablethunderbird] how to reduce saved mails?

subject: [Portablethunderbird] how to reduce saved mails?

text:
PDT wrote:

 > The problem is that the amount of my saved mails are daily growing
 > larger. It is no problem in the machine but a real problem in the USB.
 >
 > Is there anyway to remove mails saved in the profile of the Portable
 > Thunderbird in my USB, and yet manage to use POP? I needn't keep them
 > there.

PDT,

You have a couple of options.  You can selectively copy over bits of your mail store.  If you look inside your profile directory, you'll see individual directories and files that correspond to your mail folders. What you could do is create an Archive folder (for easy identification) and keep all your older mail you don't want to take with you inside that.  Then, copy all your mail folders over except that one (and sub-folders).  It's actually just a big bunch of text files, so you can really do what you'd like with them.

Also, you should compact your folders on a regular basis to save space.   Deleted messages are not removed until you do... even if you empty trash.  Just click on any Local Folder and then select FILE and then Compact Folders from the main menu.

Regards,
John

-- 
John T. Haller

Personal Site: http://johnhaller.com/
Web Development: http://rareideas.com/

subject: [Portablethunderbird] Re: how to reduce saved mails?

text:
Hello,

I'm trying to install Thunderbird for Windows and Linux on my USB Stick and share my profile between them.
As it seems not to be possible to use the same profile folder for both Linux and Windows (as there are system specific components in it) it is necessary to have two profile folders and to create symbolic links for the mail folder, the address book and so on.
The problem is: with Linux it is not possible to create symbolic links as the USB Stick uses the VFAT file system; Windows links can be created but Thunderbird does not except them (i.e. no mails appear in Thunderbird).
Is there any possibility to circumvent these problems?

Regards
Carsten Scharfenberg

headers.subject: [Portablethunderbird] How to share mails between Linux and Windows on USB-Stick?

subject: [Portablethunderbird] How to share mails between Linux and Windows on USB-Stick?

text:
Carsten Scharfenberg wrote:

> I'm trying to install Thunderbird for Windows and Linux on my USB
> Stick and share my profile between them. As it seems not to be
> possible to use the same profile folder for both Linux and Windows
> (as there are system specific components in it) it is necessary to
> have two profile folders and to create symbolic links for the mail
> folder, the address book and so on. The problem is: with Linux it is
> not possible to create symbolic links as the USB Stick uses the VFAT
> file system; Windows links can be created but Thunderbird does not
> except them (i.e. no mails appear in Thunderbird). Is there any
> possibility to circumvent these problems?

Carsten,

You will need to manually (or automatically) copy specific files between the 2 profiles.  I'm pretty sure you can copy over your whole mailstore (imapmail and mail) as well as most other files.  The issues arise in the prefs.js when it references local file paths as Windows and Linux treat these differently.

Regards,
John

-- 
John T. Haller

Personal Site: http://johnhaller.com/
Web Development: http://rareideas.com/

text:
Hi,

Bloody good idea, this.  Thanks Jeff :) !

I want to install portable Thunderbird on a USB stick for my personal
email, but since I'll often access this from my work PC - which also
uses Thunderbird, I'd like to check if there are any precautions I need
to take to prevent one or other mail store getting corrupted.

1) Will portable Thunderbird access registry settings, files, or
anything else from my normal installation?

2) Can I run a "normal" and portable Thunderbird session at the same
time?  (e.g. double-click Thunderbird on my desktop, then plug in USB
stick and double-click Thunderbird.exe there).

Thanks very much,

Mark.

subject: [Portablethunderbird] Portable and regular Thunderbird interactions with different accounts

text:
bandwidthnz-mozilla@yahoo.co.nz wrote:

> Bloody good idea, this.  Thanks Jeff :) !
> > I want to install portable Thunderbird on a USB stick for my personal
> email, but since I'll often access this from my work PC - which also
> uses Thunderbird, I'd like to check if there are any precautions I need
> to take to prevent one or other mail store getting corrupted.
> > 1) Will portable Thunderbird access registry settings, files, or
> anything else from my normal installation?
> > 2) Can I run a "normal" and portable Thunderbird session at the same
> time?  (e.g. double-click Thunderbird on my desktop, then plug in USB
> stick and double-click Thunderbird.exe there).
> > Thanks very much,

Mark,

Everything with portable thunderbird is self-contained with the exception of the single file and directoy it generates locally listed in known issues.

You can't run both at the same time right now, but with the 1.0.2 release next week that gets the snazzy new launcher you can.

Regards,
John

-- 
John T. Haller

Personal Site: http://johnhaller.com/
Web Development: http://rareideas.com/

text:
All,

Does Portable Thunderbird, or an extension of it, allow one to limit download of either headers or full messages for "Last 3 days" or some other temporal limit like Pocket Outlook and some others do?  I have a lot of email stored up on the server and I can't open it up because PT tells me it's too much for my 128 MB drive.  I really only ever want to download the last three days or so of email to my drive using Portable Thunderbird.

Mark Cyzyk

received: (qmail 24573 invoked from network); 29 Apr 2005 18:24:00 -0000
from rwcrmhc11.comcast.net (204.127.198.35) by mozdev.org with SMTP; 29 Apr 2005 18:24:00 -0000
from comcast.net (crow.cer.jhu.edu[128.220.212.23]) by comcast.net (rwcrmhc11) with ESMTP id <2005042918162701300gehphe>; Fri, 29 Apr 2005 18:16:27 +0000
headers.user-agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows; U; Windows NT 5.1; en-US; rv:1.6) Gecko/20040113
headers.subject: [Portablethunderbird] Last 3 days...

subject: [Portablethunderbird] Last 3 days...

text:
Mark Cyzyk wrote:

> Does Portable Thunderbird, or an extension of it, allow one to limit > download of either headers or full messages for "Last 3 days" or some > other temporal limit like Pocket Outlook and some others do?  I have a > lot of email stored up on the server and I can't open it up because PT > tells me it's too much for my 128 MB drive.  I really only ever want to > download the last three days or so of email to my drive using Portable > Thunderbird.

Mark,

Thunderbird can only do headers-only or full messages.  It can't just take a specific timeframe, I believe.  How to do this is explained on the project page.

If your inbox is that large, I would suggest moving some messages to other folders on the server.  If you are using POP, you'd only be seeing the active messages in your inbox.  If you are using IMAP, you can selectively subscribe to the inbox folder but not your archive folders.

In short, the answer is to cut down your inbox as a workaround.

Regards,
John

-- 
John T. Haller

Personal Site: http://johnhaller.com/
Web Development: http://rareideas.com/

received: (qmail 57945 invoked from network); 29 Apr 2005 22:25:56 -0000
from rwcrmhc11.comcast.net (204.127.198.35) by mozdev.org with SMTP; 29 Apr 2005 22:25:56 -0000
from [10.7.0.14] (unknown[12.147.71.60]) by comcast.net (rwcrmhc11) with ESMTP id <2005042922182701300geg1re>; Fri, 29 Apr 2005 22:18:27 +0000
headers.subject: [Portablethunderbird] [Portable Thunderbird] Can't save to send or drafts folder

subject: [Portablethunderbird] [Portable Thunderbird] Can't save to send or drafts folder

text:
drbolt wrote:
> For some reason I cannot save to the Sent Items or Draft folders.  I am > sending and receiving fine, but the progress dialog just seems to go on > forever until I cancel it.  It doesn't freeze, it just sits there with > the green bar going across the little box in the bottom right.

Are you using IMAP or are you saving locally to the Local Folders?  If IMAP, then it may be a server issue and I would recommend removing the account from PTB and then re-adding it.  If Local, then perhaps the folder is corrupt.  You can delete it from your profile (not from within PTB) manually and PTB will recreate it.  Are you using the included profile or a local one that you moved into it?  Local profiles are currently incompatible and may cause issues like this.

Regards,
John

-- 
John T. Haller

Personal Site: http://johnhaller.com/
Web Development: http://rareideas.com/

text:
Portable Thunderbird 1.0.6 Beta has been released. For the unfamiliar, Portable Thunderbird is a fully-functional package of Thunderbird designed for removable media, allowing you to carry Thunderbird around with you on a removable drive (USB thumbdrive, portable hard drive, iPod, etc). This new release uses Thunderbird 1.0.6 as its base and now includes support for the Mozilla Calendar extension as well as split directory structures (seperate Apps and Data) as detailed in the readme.txt.

Download Portable Thunderbird 1.0.6 Beta:
http://johnhaller.com/jh/mozilla/portable_thunderbird/

The Portable Thunderbird Launcher 1.1.0 is also available:
http://johnhaller.com/jh/mozilla/portable_thunderbird/#launcher

Any comments or questions can be posted to this thread:
http://forums.mozillazine.org/viewtopic.php?p=1618892

Regards,
John

headers.subject: [Portablethunderbird] how to get Portablethunderbird source code

subject: [Portablethunderbird] how to get Portablethunderbird source code

text:
2smallhead wrote:
> Hello All
> 
>       Hi, my name is Golden . I am interesting in the project of 
> Portablethunderbird . I want to trace Portablethunderbird source 
> code, I follow the way to download source code but the cvs 
> portablethunderbird/src directory is empty. How can I do for downloading
> the Portablethunderbird source code??

The code for the launcher is included with PTB in the
PortableThunderbirdCode directory.  You can also download just the
launcher and code from the Source Forge project page:
https://sourceforge.net/projects/portabletbird/

Regards,
John
